responses.q5:
I think I found it confusing from the beginning until the end. Even though I understand the concept of using LLM's and human language to give prompts so it can help you programme. I felt overwhelmed by all the applications (Cursor, JSON, Google Colab, LM Arena, Python) and use of other terms which to me I could not really distinguish between so I struggled to keep up with the programming itself. I was overwhelmed switching between all the apps and couldn't quite understand what each one was for in a short space of time.

I also did not quite understand the purpose of the database from the beginning. i.e. what is the point of doing all this programming to create a search engine which can be done in more simple ways i.e. control+F? I am sure there is a good answer, but I think maybe if the purpose and goal could have been described more clearly at the beginning it would have helped me get started.
responses.q6: I liked that anyone can create their own app - accessible
responses.q10: It was really good to see how AI is practiced in reality. AI and New Technology is a big and complex field, and I enjoyed the practical element - it put a face to the name in a way! Even though I haven't come out with skills I can do in my own time, it has definitely planted a seed to the potential ways I could teach myself in the future with more time.
responses.q12: Before this course, I thought programming was mathematical. Now I think it's not, but still something new I have to get my head round. It might be in English, but it is still a new format and world for me.
responses.q13: Clearer introduction. Slower, step-by-step procedures, checking in on everyone that they have completed a step, before people continue on their own with more confidence
responses.q14_why: I know many people found it easier than me so I think in general it is useful and important - but more recognition that some people might find it harder.
responses.q15: Thank you - It was really interesting and I LOVED the film Theatre of Thoughts!
